text: - [Goutham] Welcome to Amazon SES
deliverability learning series.

My name is Goutham, and I have
Rakesh here along with me,

and both of us are technical
account managers at AWS.
Throughout this video,
we will dive into the powerful monitoring

and observability features
offered by Amazon SES,

which will enable you to
gain comprehensive visibility

into your email sending
activity, sender reputation,
and potential deliverability issues.

Whether you are looking to
optimize existing campaigns
or just starting with Amazon SES,

this video will equip
you with the knowledge

to enhance your email
deliverability practices,
so let's dive in and explore
how you can leverage these tools
to improve your email monitoring
and observability strategies.

- [Rakesh] Before we dive into
the specifics of monitoring

and observability, let's
quickly have an overview
of Amazon SES.

Amazon Simple Email
Service, or Amazon SES,
is a cloud-based email sending service

designed to help businesses
communicate effectively
with their customers.
It's well to manage high-volume sending,

ensure reliable delivery,
meet compliance standards,

and offer cost-effective
solutions for various email types.
SES caters to businesses of all sizes,

supporting transactional
emails, marketing campaigns,
and automated notifications.
Let's now explore how the monitoring
and observability features of SES
can enhance your email sending strategies.
Monitoring and observability

are crucial aspects of
email delivery with SES,
as they provide valuable insights

into our sender reputation,
sending activity,
and potential deliverability issues.
Monitoring email sending with Amazon SES

can be broadly categorized
into two main aspects,
which are monitoring sender reputation
and monitoring sending activity.

So sender reputation in
Amazon SES is a measure

of the trustworthiness of
our email sending practices.

It's influenced by factors
such as bounce rates,

complaint rates, sending
history, email frontend quality,
and authentication practices.
A good sender reputation is crucial
for maintaining high deliverability rates

and avoiding potential
restrictions on your account,

whereas sending activity in
Amazon SES refers to the metrics

and data related to your
email sending operations,
like sending statistics, delivery status,
bounces, rejects, and complaints.

Monitoring sending activity
helps understand the volume
and success rate of your email campaigns.

It provides insights into
immediate delivery issues
and helps you track your research
against your sending quotas.

Overall, sender reputation
is built over time

based on your sending patterns
and incident response,
while sending activity provides immediate,
realtime data about the email sending.
Additionally, sender reputation
is more about the qualitative aspects
of our email sending practices,

while sending activity focuses
on quantitative metrics
of email delivery.

Poor sender reputation
can have long-term effects
on our ability to reach inboxes,
while poor sending activity habits
can lead to immediate delivery issues.
In summary, both are important

for maintaining our email
deliverability in Amazon SES.

- [Goutham] So to start with
monitoring sender reputation,

the reputation metrics
page in Amazon SES console
offers comprehensive insights
into an account's sending reputation,

that is, the summary
section provides an overview

of reputation yield based
on historical bounce
and complaint rates that is calculated
using a representative volume of email
that reflects typical sending patterns.

The reputation metrics page
also displays the current status

of our SES account, which can
be in one of several states.

For example, we can see here
the healthy status indicates
that the overall SES account is healthy,
with both bounce and complaint rates
within acceptable levels.

If these metrics exceed
certain thresholds,
the account may be placed under review.
During this review period,

the status might change to
pending end of review decision

as Amazon SES evaluates the
account sending practices.

In cases where serious
issues are detected,

Amazon SES might implement
a sending paused status
to prevent further impact on reputation,

and your ability to send
emails using this AWS account

will also be impacted until
this issue is resolved.

Each of these statuses
reflect different stages

of account health and potential
actions taken by Amazon SES

to maintain overall system
integrity and sender reputation.

Also, the reputation metrics
page here shows key statistics,
which include the number of emails sent

in the last 24 hours,
remaining send capacity,

and the percentage of
daily sending quota used,

so Amazon SES encourages
regularly monitoring these metrics
to maintain a healthy reputation.

These statistics might serve
as early status indicators,
allowing us to address potential issues

before they significantly
impact email deliverability,

and we can also set up
alarms in CloudWatch

for monitoring SES sender
reputation, that is,

Amazon CloudWatch offers
extensive monitoring capabilities

for email sending
activities using Amazon SES.

All the major key metrics,
such as number of email sends,
bounces, complaints, rejects, deliveries,

and if configured, even
open and clickthrough rates
are available in Amazon CloudWatch.
These metrics offer valuable insights

into the performance and
health of email campaigns.

So CloudWatch allows for the
creation of custom alarms
based on the SES metrics.

Users can set results
for various parameters,

such as high bounce rates,
increased complaints,
or approaching sending quota or limits.
When these thresholds are met or exceeded,
CloudWatch can trigger notifications,

enabling proactive management
of email sending reputation.
This capability empowers users
to stay ahead of potential issues,
ensuring optimal email deliverability

and maintaining a healthy
sender reputation.
Also, Amazon SES leverages SNDS,
that is, Smart Network Data Services,

a Microsoft-provided tool
to monitor the reputation
of dedicated IP addresses.

SNDS provides key metrics,
such as spam rates,

complaint rates, email
acceptance percentages,
and specific indicators, like tar pits.
By monitoring these indicators,
we can identify potential issues early,

such as unusually high spam
rates or unexpected tar pits.
This data enables proactive adjustments
to sending practices,

thereby helping maintain a
positive sender reputation,
and to safeguard sender reputation.
Amazon SES also offers the ability
to temporarily pause email sending.

This can be implemented using
Amazon CloudWatch and Lambda,

creating an automated solution
that pauses email sending

when reputation metrics, such
as bounce or complaint rates,
exceed predefined thresholds.
This flexible pausing mechanism

enables proactive management
of sender reputation,

helping to maintain high
deliverability standards

and address potential issues
before resuming email sending.

- [Rakesh] Moving on to
monitoring sending activity
with Amazon SES,

let's begin with the Amazon
SES account dashboard.
The Amazon SES account dashboard,
accessible from the SES console,
offers a comprehensive overview

of email sending activity
and account health.

It begins by displaying
account-level details,

such as production access
status and sending limits.

Within that dashboard,
the daily email usage pane

offers a snapshot of
recent sending activity,

the number of emails sent
in the past 24 hours,
the remaining send quota,

and the percentage of daily
quota that's been used.

Thus, sending limits
section compliments this

by outlining daily quotas
and maximum send rates,

giving a clear picture of
the account's capabilities.

Lastly, the dashboard presents
the current account status,

which can be categorized
as healthy, under review,
or paused, giving an immediate indication
of the overall account status.

Moving on, we have the
sending statistics section

that features graphs for four
key metrics, which are sends,
rejects, bounces, and complaints.

These graphs can be
customized to display data
for a period ranging from one to 14 days,
with an aggregation interval of one hour.
This flexibility allows for both immediate

and historical analysis
of sending patterns.
Each graph on the dashboard is equipped
with a view in CloudWatch button,

which redirects to the
Amazon CloudWatch console
for advanced metric analysis.

In summary, regular monitoring
of the SES account dashboard

provides visibility into
email sending activities

and helps detect any anomalies
in email sending patterns.
This proactive approach
not only ensures smooth email operations,
but also enables early detection
and mitigation of potential issues,

ultimately supporting optimal
email sending performance.
Amazon SES offers powerful API operations

for programmatically monitoring
email sending activities.
These APIs are readily accessible

through multiple interfaces,
which are AWS SDKs,

AWS Command Line Interface,
that is, AWS CLI,
and AWS Management Console.

Irrespective whether you're
using AWS SDKs, AWS CLI,
or managing through a web interface,
Amazon SES provides flexibility
in utilizing the API operations

to match various operational
needs and differences.

Let's dive into some of the
API operations that SES offers
for monitoring email sending activity.

First is the get send
statistics API operation,

which retrieves aggregate
statistics about emails sent
from an account over the past two weeks,

including data points for
delivery attempts, bounces,

complaints, and rejections
in 15-minute increments.

Next, we have the get
domain statistics report

API operation that retrieves
detailed inbox placement
and engagement rates for specific domains
used in email sending.
For account-level information,

we have the get account API
Operation that provides details

about the email sending
status of the account,

and we have the get account
sending enabled API operation,
which indicates whether email sending
is currently enabled for the account.

Finally, we have the get
send quota API operation

that provides information on
the current sending limits

of the account, which
also includes information

on the maximum send rate
and daily sending quota

along with the usage
over the last 24 hours.
These APIs are readily accessible

through multiple interfaces,
which are AWS SDKs,

AWS Command Line Interface,
that is, AWS CLI,
and the AWS Management Console.

In summary, the SES API can
be used to create scripts

or applications that
automate email sending
and monitor statistics in real time.

This automation allows for
comprehensive management

of email activities, from
observing long-term trends
and quickly address any immediate changes
in sending activity.
Event publishing feature in Amazon SES

offers detailed information
about various events

that occurred during the
email sending process,
that is, from the initial email sending
to the final recipient interaction.
To set up event publishing,

Amazon SES needs to be
configured to send event data

to other AWS services,
such as Amazon CloudWatch,
Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose,
Amazon Simple Notification Service,
Amazon Pinpoint, or Amazon EventBridge.
This configuration can be done

through the Amazon SES
console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs,

where we need to specify
which events we want to track
and also the destination
where the event data should be sent.
Event publishing captures a wide range

of email sending events,
providing detailed insights
into email delivery and engagement.

These events include successful
sends, delivery attempts,

hard and soft bounces,
complaints, email rejections,
and rendering failures.

Beyond delivery metrics,
SES event publishing
also captures recipient engagement data.

This includes tracking
when recipients open emails
or click on links within them.
Additionally, event publishing

also captures
subscription-related actions,

such as a recipient
updating their preferences
using unsubscribe links.

Amazon SES offers several
destination options
for event publishing,

providing flexibility in how
we can analyze and respond
to email sending events.

To begin with, for those
events needing immediate
or real-time notifications
or wanting to trigger custom workflows,

Amazon Simple Notification
Service, or Amazon SNS,
can be chosen as the event destination.
Next, we have Amazon CloudWatch,
which serves as a centralized logging
and monitoring solution for SES events.

For more advanced data
processing and analytics,

we can use Amazon Kinesis Data
Firehose as a destination,

which can send real-time
streaming of event data

into other AWS services, like
Amazon S3 or Amazon Redshift.

Amazon Pinpoint serves as
another potential destination,
ideal for integrating email event data

with broader customer
engagement strategies
across multiple channels.
Lastly, we have Amazon EventBridge

that can receive Amazon
SES event publishing data
and route it to various AWS services

or external applications
based on defined rules.

In summary, each of these
destination options cater

to different use cases and
technical requirements,

allowing flexibility to select
the most appropriate solution

for handling and analyzing
email sending events.
- [Goutham] And at last,

to one of our latest
feature additions on SES,
the Virtual Deliverability Manager.
The Virtual Deliverability Manager,

or shortly called as VDM, is
an advanced deliverability tool

designed to help users
optimize email deliverability.

It provides personalized
guidance and actionable insights
to improve email sending practices
and maintain a positive sender reputation.

At the heart of VDM is its
comprehensive dashboard,
which displays critical information,

such as inbox placement
rates, engagement metrics,
and reputation scores
across various internet service providers.

It also highlights trends
and potential issues,
which helps in quickly identifying areas
that need attention.

Complementing the VDM
dashboard is the VDM Advisor,

an intelligent system
that constantly analyzes

the verified identities in SES
account for potential issues
and provide tailored recommendations
to resolve these issues.
The VDM Advisor acts
as a personal email deliverability expert
for improving sending practices
and maintaining a positive reputation.

In terms of pricing, Virtual
Deliverability Manager

is offered as an add-on
service to Amazon SES.

The cost is based on the number
of emails sent through SES,
with pricing tiers

that can accommodate
various sending volumes.

So we have talked about
observability and monitoring
with SES throughout this video.
To further explore these concepts,
we have this Amazon SES workshop built
with Amazon Simple Email Service,

which provides guidance
on managing email sending
and optimizing performance.
Specifically, lab three of this workshop

provides information on
using configuration sets
to publish events.

These labs can guide us
through publishing events
by setting up notifications through SMS,
configuring events with CloudWatch,
and using Kinesis Data Firehose to track
and analyze email sending metrics.
This lab also provides the steps to set up

and use Amazon SES Virtual
Deliverability Manager
to enhance email deliverability.

Overall, this lab is a
practical demonstration

to observe and monitor
email sending with SES.
More information on the workshop
is included in the description below.

To summarize, we have covered
a wide range of monitoring

and observability tools
available in Amazon SES.

These tools empower us
to gain deep insights
into the email sending performance,
proactively address potential issues,
and optimize email campaigns.
By leveraging these features,

we can maintain a strong
sender reputation,
ensure high deliverability rates,
and ultimately achieve greater success
in our email communication strategies.
This is the end

of Amazon SES email
deliverability learning series
focused on monitoring and observability.
